description: Mid-17th century, borrowed from Italian chiaroscuro, from chiaro (“clear, bright”) + oscuro (“dark, obscure”).

adjectives.description: chiaroscuro (comparative more chiaroscuro, superlative most chiaroscuro)

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Possessing the qualities of a work of chiaroscuro.

nouns.description: chiaroscuro (countable and uncountable, plural chiaroscuros or chiaroscuri)

entries.meaning: (painting) An artistic technique developed during the Renaissance, referring to the use of strong contrasts between light and dark in order to create the illusion of volume.
(painting) A monochrome picture made by using several different shades of the same color.
(art) A woodcut technique in which several woodcut blocks are used to print different shades of a color, or a woodcut print made by this technique.
(photography) A photographic technique in which one side of the subject, for example a face, is well lit and the other is in shadow.
